awd_titl_txt: A New Computational Approach for Wave Propagation
awd_abstract_narration:
Wave motion is the key mechanism of interest to many fields of science, such as mechanics, acoustics, seismology, oceanography, coastal and offshore engineering, electromagnetism, etc. Despite an extreme variety of physical appearances of wave phenomena, mathematical models and numerical methods implemented from them face reliability and accuracy concerns, especially at high frequencies and under impact loadings. This award will support research on a new numerical approach with optimal accuracy for wave propagation. The new modeling technique will be able to provide accurate solutions for a broad range of civil and military applications related to national health and security, respectively, where wave propagation is a concern. The project will provide opportunities to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students on the theoretical and modeling aspects of wave propagation, with a focus on underrepresented students. A workshop on dynamic behavior will also be developed for high school teachers under this project.

Many modern numerical techniques based on weak-form formulations of partial differential equations do not provide optimal accuracy in the discrete equations. This leads to a prohibitively large computation time for real-world wave propagation problems. In this project, a novel high-order numerical approach for wave propagation on Cartesian meshes for irregular domains will be directly formulated in terms of discrete equations with unknown coefficients. These coefficients are calculated by the minimization of the local truncation error and provide the optimal order of accuracy. Some of the important applications will include high-frequency wave propagation in the Hopkinson Bar and elastic wave propagation in the vicinity of crack tips and defects. Due to stationary Cartesian meshes, there will be no need to remesh the domain for a moving crack. The moving crack will be treated by the corresponding high-order boundary conditions on the same Cartesian grid.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wave motion is the key mechanism of interest to many fields of science, such as solid mechanics, acoustics, seismology, oceanography, coastal and offshore engineering, electromagnetism, etc. There are the following difficulties with existing numerical approaches for wave propagation: a) accurate numerical solutions of many real-world time-dependent wave propagation problems require a prohibitively large computation time; b) computational conforming meshes for irregular domains often include small cut cells; this leads to a significant decrease in accuracy; c) many modern numerical techniques based on weak formulations do not provide the optimal accuracy of final discrete equations.

We have developed a new numerical approach for wave propagation that provides optimal accuracy on trivial unfitted Cartesian meshes for complex irregular domains. The main outcomes can be summarized as follows.

The new developed numerical approach (called the Optimal Local Truncation Error Method or OLTEM) uses simple compact discrete equations with unknown coefficients that are calculated by the minimization of the local truncation error. It provides the maximum possible order of accuracy that cannot be improved without changing the width of discrete equations.  At the same computational costs (the same width of discrete equations), OLTEM is much more accurate than such popular modern numerical approaches as finite elements, isogeometric elements, spectral elements and other high-order methods. Usually, the increase in accuracy by one order is a significant result. However, the increase in accuracy by OLTEM is much higher. For example, at the computational costs of quadratic finite elements, OLTEM provides 10-th order of accuracy for elasticity problems on complex geometry, i.e., the increase by 7 orders (!) compared to quadratic finite elements. Numerical experiments show that a huge increase in accuracy by OLTEM leads to an extremely large reduction in computation time (by a factor of 1000 - 10000 and more) compared to existing numerical approaches at a given accuracy. We have applied OLTEM with unfitted Cartesian meshes to the simulations of high-frequency wave propagation on complex irregular geometry that are done on a laptop computer (such simulations would require a supercomputer with existing techniques). We have also developed new high-order boundary conditions and post processing procedure for the calculation of the spatial derivatives of numerical solutions (e.g., stresses for elasticity) that can be also used for the accuracy increase of known numerical techniques.  OLTEM is a revolutionary new approach for the derivation of numerical methods with optimal accuracy. For the first time the optimal accuracy of discrete equations used for the solution of partial differential equations has been identified and reached with OLTEM. Due to general ideas, OLTEM can be developed not only for wave propagation but also for general partial differential equations that describe different physical phenomenon. We strongly believe that in the future OLTEM will replace many existing numerical techniques. The results obtained during the NSF project have been published in 19 long fundamental papers (two other papers are under review) in the leading scientific journals. In addition to promoting fundamental research on numerical techniques, the new approach is important for a broad range of civil and military applications related to national health and prosperity as well as national security.
